articles.headline: Why the Supreme Court’s Rulings Have Profound Implications for American Politics
articles.snippet: The justices handed Republicans a key victory by refusing to halt even the most extreme gerrymandered maps. But Democrats may have a win on blocking the citizenship question from the census.
articles.abstract: The justices handed Republicans a key victory by refusing to halt even the most extreme gerrymandered maps. But Democrats may have a win on blocking the citizenship question from the census.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The rulings by the Supreme Court on Thursday in bitterly contested battles over partisan gerrymandering and the addition of a citizenship question to the 2020 census grappled with issues fundamental to the nation’s democracy: How power is allocated, and ultimately, how much of a voice the American people have in selecting their leaders.

articles.headline: Trade War Has Damaged U.S. Chip Industry in Ways a Deal May Never Fix
articles.snippet: Beyond the current financial hit, American producers fear Chinese companies will strengthen domestic manufacturing and switch to other foreign suppliers they consider more dependable.
articles.abstract: Beyond the current financial hit, American producers fear Chinese companies will strengthen domestic manufacturing and switch to other foreign suppliers they consider more dependable.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Alex Lidow has sold semiconductors in China for decades, starting at a company, called International Rectifier, that his father and grandfather founded in the Los Angeles area in 1947.

articles.headline: The RealReal I.P.O.: Secondhand Fashion Goes Mainstream
articles.snippet: The company, which saw its shares jump in its first day as a public company on Friday, is one of several businesses catering to younger shoppers who want brand-name goods at affordable prices.
articles.abstract: The company, which saw its shares jump in its first day as a public company on Friday, is one of several businesses catering to younger shoppers who want brand-name goods at affordable prices.
articles.lead_paragraph: It’s never been easier to shop another woman’s closet.

articles.headline: After 14 Years, Chief Justice Roberts Takes Charge
articles.snippet: A pair of stunning decisions on Thursday showed that the chief justice has replaced Justice Anthony M. Kennedy as the court’s swing vote.
articles.abstract: A pair of stunning decisions on Thursday showed that the chief justice has replaced Justice Anthony M. Kennedy as the court’s swing vote.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr. has sat in the center seat on the Supreme Court bench since his arrival in 2005. But only this term did he assume true leadership of the court.

articles.headline: Supreme Court Green-Lights Gerrymandering and Blocks Census Citizenship Question
articles.snippet: The pair of decisions have vast implications for the political landscape and democracy itself.
articles.abstract: The pair of decisions have vast implications for the political landscape and democracy itself.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In a pair of decisions with vast implications for the American political landscape, the Supreme Court on Thursday delivered a victory to Republicans by ruling that federal courts are powerless to hear challenges to extreme partisan gerrymandering but gave a reprieve to Democrats by delaying the Trump administration’s efforts to add a question on citizenship to the 2020 census.

articles.headline: Biden Comes Under Attack From All Sides in Democratic Debate
articles.snippet: Senator Kamala Harris confronted the former vice president in a searing moment over racial equality, and others attacked him on policy and generational divide.
articles.abstract: Senator Kamala Harris confronted the former vice president in a searing moment over racial equality, and others attacked him on policy and generational divide.
articles.lead_paragraph: MIAMI — Joseph R. Biden Jr. repeatedly found himself on the defensive in the Democratic debate on Thursday over his record as well as his personal views, with the most searing moment of the night, and the primary campaign to date, coming when Senator Kamala Harris confronted him over his comments on working with segregationists in the Senate.
articles.byline: By Jonathan Martin and Alexander Burns

articles.headline: ‘Very Smart People,’ but a Keyless Car’s Downside Killed Them
articles.snippet: A couple with careers in academia and science died of carbon-monoxide poisoning. A second congressional bill has been introduced to mandate safety features.
articles.abstract: A couple with careers in academia and science died of carbon-monoxide poisoning. A second congressional bill has been introduced to mandate safety features.
articles.lead_paragraph: For Sherry H. Penney, a former university chancellor, and her husband, James D. Livingston, a retired physicist, the 2017 Toyota Avalon was a sensible purchase. It was a model she and her husband had owned before, but the new version had electronic sensors and other advanced features.

articles.headline: A Unicorn Lost in the Valley, Evernote Blows Up the ‘Fail Fast’ Gospel
articles.snippet: In this season of multibillion-dollar I.P.O.s, the 15-year-old start-up is proving that failure, for companies of a certain size, rarely happens abruptly.
articles.abstract: In this season of multibillion-dollar I.P.O.s, the 15-year-old start-up is proving that failure, for companies of a certain size, rarely happens abruptly.
articles.lead_paragraph: Smiling cryptically, Ian Small, the chief executive of Evernote, handed me some socks. Nice ones: black in the calf, striped in the foot, with matching pops of sky blue at the toe, heel and welt. The knit was Japanese, dense and springy, and contained 1 percent polyurethane. Marketing language described them, insanely, as “smart covers for your feet” that shared design principles with productivity software.

articles.headline: Trump and Putin Share Joke About Election Meddling, Sparking New Furor
articles.snippet: At the leaders’ first formal meeting in a year, President Trump again made clear that he does not take Russia’s electoral interference as seriously as others do.
articles.abstract: At the leaders’ first formal meeting in a year, President Trump again made clear that he does not take Russia’s electoral interference as seriously as others do.
articles.lead_paragraph: OSAKA, Japan — They were having a good time. Like old friends reuniting, they warmly shook hands, smiled and chatted amiably. And then President Trump brushed off Russia’s interference in American democracy with a joke as President Vladimir V. Putin chuckled.
articles.byline: By Peter Baker and Michael Crowley

articles.headline: It’s Now the Supreme Court’s Turn to Try to Resolve the Fate of the Dreamers
articles.snippet: After a long delay, the justices agreed to decide whether the Trump administration may shut down a program known as DACA that shields young immigrants from deportation.
articles.abstract: After a long delay, the justices agreed to decide whether the Trump administration may shut down a program known as DACA that shields young immigrants from deportation.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — For seven years, the so-called Dreamers — nearly 800,000 young men and women who were brought to the United States illegally as children — have lived in limbo, protected from immediate deportation but without the guarantee of any permanent future in the United States.
articles.byline: By Michael D. Shear and Adam Liptak

articles.headline: Trump’s Case for China Tariffs Fails to Persuade Americans
articles.snippet: A survey finds that voters think the trade measures will be bad for the United States, and that even most Republicans say they will lead to higher prices.
articles.abstract: A survey finds that voters think the trade measures will be bad for the United States, and that even most Republicans say they will lead to higher prices.
articles.lead_paragraph: As President Trump weighs a possible resolution to his trade conflict with China, one factor may be pushing him toward a deal: His trade policies are broadly unpopular with American voters.
articles.byline: By Ben Casselman and Jim Tankersley

articles.headline: Subway Got Too Big. Franchisees Paid a Price.
articles.snippet: Sabotaged meatballs. The wrong soap. Franchisees say supervisors manipulated inspections — then took their stores. A company ‘hit man’ says it’s true.
articles.abstract: Sabotaged meatballs. The wrong soap. Franchisees say supervisors manipulated inspections — then took their stores. A company ‘hit man’ says it’s true.
articles.lead_paragraph: Manoj Tripathi couldn’t shake the feeling that someone had a vendetta against his Subway sandwich shop. A franchisee for nearly two decades, he had done everything he could to keep his restaurant, in a strip mall in Northern California, in perfect condition. But lately it seemed like someone was out to get him.
articles.byline: By Tiffany Hsu and Rachel Abrams
